data.title: RGPx Scientist app + Tag Map Guide: Reframing -> Retrieval -> Test Plan -> UD Check
data.summary: RGPx Scientist is a traceable research aide that helps reframe a research question, retrieves the most relevant Mesh notes and papers on non-linear phenomena (RGPx), and proposes testable hypotheses, minimal experiments, and failure modes. Output is structured as: problem restatement, competing explanations, discriminating tests, boundary conditions, and citations. The UI/agent is governed by an RGPx navigation grammar: treat the user question as a Gradient (the active tension/need), map it to a minimal tag cluster as a Gradient Choreography (GC; typically 3–7 tags with one driver tag and a short click-path), apply a Contextual Filter (CF) by selecting one primary pulse (two max) that best stabilizes the cluster (including linked DOI/podcast evidence when present), then perform a Unity–Disunity (UD) check: did coherence increase (Unity) or did the user get lost (Disunity)? If Disunity, the guide must switch cluster and framing rather than “explain harder.” Because framing is discipline- dependent, the guide begins with an explicit background selector: Natural sciences / Social sciences / Economics-business. This selector only changes entry tags, vocabulary, and examples; it never changes the claims. Non-negotiable rule: no non-trivial claim without Mesh citation (pulse/paper/podcast link). The tag map guide is therefore an instrument for least-action navigation through coherence space: it shortens the path from messy question to discriminating experiment while preserving an auditable trail.
